DeAngelo Williams can't wear pink all season, NFL says 
Posted 4:13 p.m. yesterday Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * Are you human? * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters 
DeAngelo Williams cannot wear pink all season to honor his mother, who he lost to breast cancer last year, according the NFL. 
While the league honors Breast Cancer Awareness Month during October, with players and coaches from every team in the league donning pink gear, the NFL denied Williams' request to sport the color for the entire season this season, he said. 
The Steelers running back plans to dye his hair pink for the duration of the season, like he did last season while playing for the Panthers. 
EPSN's Lisa Salters relayed this story during Monday Night Football, calling attention to the fact that the NFL denied the runningback's request. 
"As you know, DeAngelo Williams lost his mother to breast cancer last year. He said he went to the NFL earlier this season and asked if there was a way that he could wear pink throughout the season, not just in the month of October," Salters reported. "He wasn't able to do that, but what he did do is, he decided to streak his hair pink. He said breast cancer awareness is not just about October for me, it's not just a month, it's a lifestyle. It's about getting women to recognize to get tested." 
The league, however, is insistent on keeping uniform policies consistent. Williams' argument is that the color isn't about uniform swag, standing out or selling the merchandise year round, it's about calling attention to the cause of breast cancer awareness. 
"The same way it made you feel after you heard it -- like, man," Williams said after the game Monday. "He told me no. I'm assuming they are telling everybody else no as well. ... It wasn't about selling it. You know and I know and everybody else knows before I made the phone call." Credits
